title: Bipartisan Immigration Reform Bill Gains Momentum with 70 Senate Votes
introText: A comprehensive immigration reform bill has secured 70 Senate votes, clearing the filibuster threshold and advancing to the House. The legislation combines enhanced border security with pathways to legal status and modernized visa systems.

content.content: Immigration reform advances with bipartisan support

The Border Security and Immigration Reform Act passed the Senate 70-30, marking the first major immigration legislation to advance since 1986. The bill emerged from months of negotiations between a bipartisan group of senators.
Twenty Republicans joined all Democrats in supporting the measure. Key GOP supporters cited the need for legal workforce solutions while maintaining border security priorities.
The bill allocates $25 billion for border infrastructure and technology over five years. It mandates E-Verify for all employers and increases penalties for hiring undocumented workers.
Critically, the legislation creates a 10-year path to legal status for undocumented immigrants who have lived in the US for at least seven years, pass background checks, and pay back taxes and fines.

The bill reforms the visa system, increasing H-1B caps for high-skilled workers and creating new agricultural worker categories. Family reunification backlogs would be addressed through additional visa allocations.
Dreamers â€“ those brought to the US as children â€“ receive a direct path to citizenship under the legislation, resolving their long-uncertain status.

House passage remains uncertain, with conservative Republicans expressing opposition to any legalization provisions. Speaker has not committed to bringing the bill to the floor but faces pressure from moderate members and business groups.

summary: A bipartisan immigration reform bill with 70 Senate votes advances, offering border security, legal status pathways, and visa modernization, but faces uncertain prospects in the House.
